manufacturerProductDescription.media_text: The Other Einstein The Only Woman in the Room Lady Clementine The Mystery of Mrs. Christie Her Hidden Genius The Mitford Affair Don’t miss these inspiring reads from Marie Benedict! The story of not-so-famous scientist Mileva Marić, who not only loved Albert Einstein, but also shaped the theories that brought him lasting renown. Based on the incredible true story of the glamour icon and scientist Hedy Lamarr, this book celebrates the many women in science that history has overlooked. The ferocious story of Clementine Churchill, the ambitious woman who did not flinch through the sweeping darkness of war, and who would not surrender to expectations or to enemies. A thrilling reconstruction of one of the most notorious events in literary history: Agatha Christie's mysterious 11-day disappearance in 1926. Shines a light on Rosalind Franklin, whose world-changing contributions were hidden by the men around her but whose relentless drive advanced our understanding of humankind. An explosive novel of history's most notorious sisters, one of whom will have to choose: her country or her family?

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A beautiful story
reviews.reviewText: Marie Benedict has a talent for bringing her characters to life and weaving them into your soul. I loved getting to immerse myself in post industrial American culture, learn about society and business and experience the arts.Clara and Andrew have embedded themselves into my brains and made me want to learn more.I love how Benedict uses every person to tell A tale of legacy and life. No matter status or wealth we ALL have a history worth recording and leave marks in the annals of history beyond the scope of our mere mortal understanding.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars I loved this book until…
reviews.reviewText: I thought this was a beautiful book. Well researched, complex characters and interesting. There were times where the letter writing felt a little unnatural eg teaching us about Irish history that these two women would have already known about. That could be easily overlooked. I did however, struggle with the ending. It felt sudden and a little frustrating. I understand it’s mr Carnegie, so they couldn’t be together. But she couldn’t write him a letter a few years later? Meet him in the library? Something? It felt sudden and like it needed a proper sense of closure. She had also revealed her family’s address to him in the argument so I find it hard that he didn’t discover her before she left town. And what did it do to the relationship with his mother? So many questions

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I absolutely enjoyed this wonderful fictional story about Carnegies maid. I would enjoyed it more if Andrew had married her, that would have been some story ending lol but it was still really good, this was my first book by Marie Benedict and I've already picked my next read by her!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Very well written could not put the book down. You do not read or hear much about Camegie these days as I did growing up. Wonder why? Must be the times we are living in now. Google the internet? So sad.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2024
reviews.reviewText: You will really enjoy reading this book, and for many it will draw you in emotionally, hopefully bring in comparison with your own wonderful lives.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars An intriguing glimpse into an era
reviews.reviewText: I enjoyed this fictionalized story about Andrew Carnegie and a possible romance that changed his life. Of course, the romantic in me would have preferred a HEA, but it was still a good read.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars I loved it
reviews.reviewText: And like others had trouble putting it down. I’m also Irish, am very familiar with Pittsburgh and found the details of the lives involved and descriptions of the settings accurate.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Growing up in Carnegie's city, Pittsburgh, I was so excited to read this story. This book did not dissapoint. It was a very interesting look at not only Andrew Carnegie's personal life, but also his many business achieve-ments. I like to think that his love of Clara Kelley was true.

love all her books about the unknown people who in someway influenced their life.Rosalind Franklin was and is an exception Historical figure in her own right and should HAVE bee the one To Win The Nobel PRIZE .... from another of Marie's books....

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on August 6, 2020
reviews.reviewText: Really enjoyed this book!Very lifelike and believable.I was sorry to come to the end of it.

This is another classic tale of a poor servant girl catching the eye of her rich master. However although our heroine, Clara, the ladies maid is fictional, her rich employer is not. He is Andrew Carnegie. So the author is constrained by history and one knows right from the start that the romance, such as it is, will never go anywhere and that is one of the novels flaws. Although the book is very well written and researched, the plot lacks drama. The romance is very chaste and is not imbued with much emotion and the premise that this woman might have influenced Carnegie’s business and philanthropic causes, really seems a bit far fetched. I also would have liked a more imaginative ending. As it is the book ends on a rather flat note. However Andrew Carnegie certainly was a vary interesting person and so I found this book most informative.
Although the character is purely fictional, the author's mastery of the period lends credence to something that one would hope would happen in real life at the time.
The book was informative, interesting and a page turner.
